subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: QS news update
msgSnippet: ... I definitely feel at this point that standardizing (or standardising!) common words will be more useful than non-common ones because we see them so often,
messageBody:
Moira O'Brien wrote:
>
>
> I rather agree with Ted, even though i am in favour of some
> standardisation, but only on common words. I have no difficulty in
> understanding
> US written scripts if I read it with and "American" accent. Likewise with any other accent - which one can usually deduce from the way certain words are written in QS.
>
>
> So vive la difference, but lets keep, and maybe slightly expand upon,
> the standardised common words.
>

I definitely feel at this point that standardizing (or standardising!)
common words will be more useful than non-common ones because we see
them so often, so we don't want to have try to figure them each time. I
have made a list of the 2,000 most commonly used words in the English
language. I got the list from some website, and it could always be
expanded. I think maybe I should post this list (I had planned on doing
this, but the pushes me), because then we can actually see the difference.

Paul
